sen.e: The most famous paintings are two pieces held by Shitenno-ji Temple (the sixth and eleventh fans of "hokkekyo" vol. 7) depicting the market in Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto), in which a woman wearing an apron is selling various commodities including fish, fruits, pepos, chestnuts and cloths in a small shop with an ikken (or 1-ken) -width frontage (1-ken is approximately 1.8 meters) and another woman wearing Ichime-gasa (a kind of cap with a shade, worn by a woman) and Uchigi (ordinary kimono) is walking before the shop.

sen.e: Another painting features women gathering around a well (the first fan of "hokkekyo" vol. 7) in which a village woman wearing no Uchigi, with a magemono (wooden bucket) on her head, leads her naked child by hand, and another woman in travel clothing, wearing Uchigi, dips up water with the use of a tsurube (a tub for a well) and drinks it; they represent the mode of life of local people in those days.

sen.e: Furthermore, the subjects of the paintings include children's play and special seasonable features, such as two girls playing kusa-awase (a game where they show various grass they bring for a competition) (the eighth fan of "hokkekyo" vol. 7), a boy trying to catch a little bird (the ninth fan of "hokkekyo" vol. 7) and harvest of persimmons (the eleventh fan of "hokkekyo" vol. 6), as well as the scene of a lady watching maple leaves and a Hashitame picking chestnuts (the tenth fan of "hokkekyo" vol. 1), Kugyo (the top court officials) reading a letter and a warawame (little girl) (the ninth fan of "hokkekyo" vol. 1) and even the scene of a yujo (prostitute) and a kairai (puppet) or okannagi (sorcerer) singing Imayo (popular style of song in Heian period) as offerings to Doso-jin (traveler's guardian deity), probably solacing the spirit.
